author: VNExplorer
title: ’Escote de la muerte’: el complejo fenómeno meteorológico que estaría afectando Chile
text: Escote de la Muerte La lluvia regresó con gran intensidad a las zonas sur y centro sur de Chile, luego de un mes de julio más bien seco. El sistema frontal ha dejado graves consecuencias en las regiones de Araucanía y Biobío, mientras se desplaza hasta la Metropolitana. Lo cierto es que algunos meteorólogos, desde antes, pronosticaron el paso de un fenómeno meteorológico conocido como ‘Escote del diablo’, o ‘Escote de la muerte’, el cual básicamente se daría en Santiago. La situación fue explicada por el meteorólogo Eduardo Sáez a La Tercera, quien sostuvo que básicamente se trata de lluvias más débiles para la capital, en comparación a lo que puede pasar en Valparaíso y la precordillera. “Se forma una configuración donde baja la concentración de precipitaciones en valles respecto a la cordillera y costa”, indicó. “El ‘escote de la muerte’ se percibe como una letra V en el mapa, porque, a raíz de los vientos, hace que el sistema frontal tome esta forma y haya una zona ‘libre’ (en este caso, la región Metropolitana) que tenga una lluvia más débil, en comparación al resto”, agregó. Por lo pronto, el profesional asegura que no se trata de un término que avizore una catástrofe, sino que más bien es parte de la jerga en aquel rubro. Expresión similar tuvo Gianfranco Marcone en Canal 13, al explicar lo que podría venir para el Gran Santiago en cuanto a lluvias. “Cuando teníamos un sistema frontal, la última parte llegaba a la zona central, esta última parte generalmente es la más débil”. “Entonces uno decía, está lloviendo en Valparaíso, Viña del Mar, en San José de Maipo, Buin, ¿Por qué no llueve en Santiago?”, concluyó. No obstante, Sáez adelanta que sí o sí existirán lluvias en el centro del país: #si uno lo mira desde la cantidad de lluvia, en Santiago no lloverá lo mismo que se espera en Valparaíso. Pero de que va a llover, va a llover igual”.

author: Nathan Langley
title: Freeport's Grand River Hall hosts family-friendly New Year's Eve | News | wrex.com
text: FREEPORT, Ill. — For families looking to ring in the new year together, Freeport's [Grand River Hall](https://grandriverhall.com/) hopes to provide safe fun. Grand River Hall, an event space in the Stephenson County community, hosts [Family Night for New Year's Eve](https://www.facebook.com/GrandRiverHall/posts/874797144646135?ref=embed_post). Family-friendly festivities are abound as a magician, local caricature artist, disco dance party and more await the night. And for grownups concerned of kiddos staying up late, the celebration holds its own ball drop at 10 p.m. "Plenty of time to head home, cuddle up to ring in the New Year with the ones you love or get yourself a sitter and head back out for a night on the town," states the [event](https://www.facebook.com/GrandRiverHall) on the early ball drop. No outside food or drinks are allowed, but light snacks and purchasable drinks can be found inside the hall. Likewise, all children must remain accompanied by an adult at all times, The Grand River Hall rings in the New Year from 6 p.m. to 10 p.m. on Sunday, Dec. 31; doors open at 6 p.m., seating for Johnny Silver Magic opens from 7 p.m. until 8 p.m. and remaining festivities run from 8 p.m. to 10 p.m. The Freeport event space is located at 101 S Liberty Ave #1, Freeport.

author: Cheryl Goodenough
title: Oztag player Benson Leipau Pauga avoids jail, deportation for punch that left referee with brain bleed
text:
After an Oztag touch footy player tearfully apologised for his
“stupid” assault on a referee that caused a brain bleed, the one-punch attack victim stepped forward to shake hands.
Benson Leipau Pauga had approached Jason Fernie in the July 2022 game’s second half after his team accused the referee of favouring the opposition, a
Brisbane court was told on Thursday.
After a verbal exchange, Pauga punched the 49-year-old Fernie on the jaw.
Know the news with the 7NEWS app:
Download today
Fernie fell backwards, hitting his head on the ground and convulsed, with blood on his mouth.
Pauga, now 34, left the sports ground while Fernie, a referee for 22 years, was taken to hospital with a brain bleed and concussion.
On the judge’s instructions, Pauga turned in the Brisbane District Court dock to face Fernie, before tearfully reading a letter of apology.
“What I did was wrong. I really made a stupid mistake,” he said.
“I hope you find it in your heart to forgive me.”
As Pauga finished, Fernie stood up and shook his hand.
It was clear from Fernie’s victim impact statement the assault had a significant emotional and physical impact on the referee and his family, Judge Paul Smith said.
The court was told Pauga described his conduct as a “blind explosion” during a week in which he separated from his wife and his scaffolding business partner had left.
“Referees need to feel safe from players but there was only one punch,” Smith said.
Taking into account Pauga’s guilty plea to one count of assault occasioning bodily harm, Smith sentenced him to a 12-month intensive corrections order and recorded a conviction.
Pauga, who was raised in West Auckland and moved to Australia in 2009, risked being deported if he was sentenced to actual time in custody.
He was ordered to pay $5000 compensation to Fernie within six months.
The court heard he has a lifetime ban from playing Oztag.
Outside court, Fernie said it was good that Pauga apologised but his actions were totally unacceptable.
Describing the legal system as pretty soft and the compensation amount “a joke”, Fernie said the outcome was disappointing and he still suffered after the assault.
“I can’t ref anymore, that’s what hurts the most. I miss my Oztag family,” he said.
Australian Oztag general manager Luke Manahan said the organisation takes a strong stance towards abuse against referees and officials.
“We know how important referees are for our game,” he told AAP.
Oztag is a non-tackling version of rugby league.

author: @mysuncoast
title: Clouds Move Out, and Sunshine Reappears for New Year’s Weekend
text: Clouds Move Out, and Sunshine Reappears for New Year’s Weekend Rip Current Statement Through Saturday 9 p.m. SARASOTA, Fla. (WWSB) - Mostly cloudy skies turn into partly cloudy skies by the morning. The overnight low temperature will hit 51 degrees. As the day progresses more sunshine appears, leading to an overall sunnier weekend. It will feel drier and less humid as dewpoints dip to the 40s. For beachgoers and boaters, a rip current statement remains in effect for the entire coast of Manatee and Sarasota county through 9 p.m., Saturday evening. Winds will come from the northwest Saturday, with gusts near 20 mph. Seas improve slightly from Friday, reaching two to four feet, and possibly five feet. Bay and inland waters will have a moderate chop to choppy conditions. Winds die down Saturday evening and conditions significantly improve for boaters Sunday and New Year’s Day. A jacket may be required to stay warm New Year’s Eve. When the pineapple drops in downtown Sarasota at midnight, the temperature will be in the low 50s. Skies will be clear, making for a great view of the fireworks. Copyright 2023 WWSB. All rights reserved.

author: BVM Sportsdesk
title: Victor Wembanyama's Season Cut Short by Injury: What It Means
text:
Victor Wembanyama’s Season Cut Short by Injury: What It Means
Victor Wembanyama's promising season has come to an abrupt end due to a diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis. This condition, which echoes the struggles faced by former player Chris Bosh, raises concerns for Wembanyama's future. Despite uncertainty, sources report that the Spurs are optimistic about his recovery, hoping to see him return at full strength by the next season. Wembanyama's impressive stats highlight his impact, averaging 24.3 points, 11 rebounds, and leading the league with 3.8 blocks per game.
- 24.3 points per game, 11 rebounds, 3.8 blocks (leading the league)
- Only five players in NBA history averaged 20-10-3-3-1 for a full season; Wembanyama has done this in each of his first two seasons.
- Rejects 10.1% of opponents' 2-point shots, the fifth-highest block rate in NBA history.
While Wembanyama's current diagnosis is concerning, comparisons to Chris Bosh's career-threatening issues highlight the potential severity of the situation. However, initial reports suggest this may be an isolated incident rather than the beginning of a recurring health issue.
State of Play- Wembanyama played only 46 games this season, falling short of the 65-game eligibility for year-end awards.
- The Spurs' playoff hopes diminish significantly without their star player, as they face a tough road ahead.
The Spurs expect Wembanyama to make a full recovery by September, allowing them to focus on building around his talent alongside newly acquired De’Aaron Fox. This situation may also push the team to secure a higher draft pick for future improvements.
Bottom LineWembanyama's season-ending diagnosis is a significant blow for the Spurs, but there is cautious optimism about his recovery. The team's focus should be on his health, as safeguarding their generational talent is crucial for long-term success.
Read more at Yahoo Sports
